Expectation1: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation1: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I was halfway through checking the ambulance’s first-aid kit, methodically counting bandages and checking expiration dates, when my phone buzzed urgently. The dispatcher’s voice was replaced by a news producer: “We need you live, now. Misinformation is spreading—your voice matters.” My heart thudded. As an ambulance driver, I knew the kit had to be perfect; missing supplies could mean the difference between life and death. But as an activist, I’d spent months preparing for moments like this, when the truth needed a champion and the community needed clarity. I glanced at the half-finished inventory, guilt prickling at the thought of leaving it incomplete. Yet, the thought of letting falsehoods go unchallenged on national television made my stomach twist. Both roles demanded my full attention, both were urgent in their own way. I stood frozen, torn between the silent, steady responsibility in my hands and the loud, immediate call to action ringing in my ear.
